info.game_comments:
2001 College Championship semifinal game 1.
From the campus at UCLA.

(1, 1).clue: Astronomy.com reminds you when to look for these events in the sky, like the Perseid ones around Aug. 11 & 12

(3, 1).clue: This star of "Casablanca" was booted out of Phillips Academy for uncontrollably high spirits

(4, 1).clue: Famous for enticing Amaterasu out of hiding, Uzume is a goddess of mirth & dancing from this Asian country

(5, 1).clue: This captain's "five year mission" actually only lasted about 3 (until syndication & films)

(6, 1).clue: Mmm... you smell like these "curiously strong peppermints"; you're wearing the cologne named for them

(1, 2).clue: In the "Astro for Kids" section, click on images of your favorite planets; the one seen here symbolizes this planet

(3, 2).clue: Perhaps responding "nevermore", this poet was expelled from West Point in 1831 for refusing to attend drills

(4, 2).clue: Akin to Quetzalcoatl of the Aztecs, Kinich Ahau was a fire-bird sun god of this Central American people

(5, 2).clue: Let's give a hand to this villain, created in 1904 by James M. Barrie

(6, 2).clue: Wow!  Un amour de patou makes you smell like this flower "of the valley"

(1, 3).clue: Astroshopping?  Check out the image stabilization type of these (opera glasses are a lower-tech type)

(3, 3).clue: Once publisher of the USA's largest newspaper chain, he was expelled from Harvard in 1885 for insulting his professors

(4, 3).clue: Hanuman, a god of this religion, leads an army of monkeys & once allied himself with Rama in an important war

(5, 3).clue: Let's give a hand (no, a leg) to this seafaring captain created in 1851

(6, 3).clue: Mmm!  You smell like sandalwood & tonka bean in this designer's cK Be cologne

(1, 4).clue: The "Fun Facts" told us how this Spanish surrealist artist thought he got messages from outer space thru his mustache

(3, 4).clue: Assassinated in August 1940, this Russian Communist leader was expelled in his youth for howling at his teacher

(4, 4).clue: Akin to the Greek Dike, Justitia was this empire's divine personification of justice

(5, 4).clue: Climb aboard the S.S. Guppy at this breakfast food mascot's website

(6, 4).clue: You smell like the bitter type of this nut, so either you're wearing Dior's Hypnotic Poison or you've swallowed cyanide

(1, 5).clue: Learn all about these objects, whose name comes from the latin for "mist"; the Eagle one is see here

(3, 5).clue: The leading actress of her time, in 1860 she was expelled from a Paris convent school for making fun of a bishop

(4, 5).clue: Depicted as both a cobra & a lioness, the goddess Wadjet protected royal authority in this ancient land

(5, 5).clue: The secret identity of this patriotic shield-sporting Marvel superhero was Steve Rogers

(6, 5).clue: I hate to be gauche, but you smell like jasmine in this designer's Rive Gauche perfume

(1, 1).clue: In 1979 this nation granted home rule to Catalonia & the Basque country

(2, 1).clue: In most cellular organisms, DNA is carried by these threadlike structures in the nucleus of a cell

(3, 1).clue: Tom Cruise plays a lawyer in trouble with his bosses in this 1993 film

(4, 1).clue: Many ideas George Mason wrote into this state's Declaration of Rights in 1776 were used in the Bill of Rights

(5, 1).clue: A nameless black protagonist narrates this 1952 classic by Ralph Ellison

(6, 1).clue: On this berry whose 2 main varieties are red & black, the little beads are called drupelets

(1, 2).clue: This Roman emperor known for his "Wall" rebuilt the Pantheon between 118 & 128 A.D.

(2, 2).clue: Humans have about 30,000 of these basic DNA units of heredity whose name is from the Greek for "birth"

(4, 2).clue: The Second Amendment says a "well regulated" one of these is "necessary to the security of a Free State"

(5, 2).clue: The name of this Toni Morrison novel (& its title character) comes from the simple inscription on a headstone

(6, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew puts a clasping gizmo in her hair.)  From the French, it's what I'm using to hold my hair back

(1, 3).clue: He became British prime minister in 1997 as the Labour Party won its largest majority since 1935

(2, 3).clue: In 1953 Watson & crick described the spiral structure of DNA as one of these

(3, 3).clue: Susan Sarandon plays a lawyer with pint-sized trouble in this 1994 film

(4, 3).clue: This man whose signature graces the Bill of Rights was president of the Senate at the time

(5, 3).clue: H.L. Mencken said, "No romantic novel ever written in America... is one half so beautiful as" this one by Willa Cather

(6, 3).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew tugs on her skirt.)  All polite young ladies should learn this respectful gesture

(1, 4).clue: The Hohenzollern family ruled Germany & Prussia for centuries until this man abdicated in 1918

(2, 4).clue: 3 types of this nucleic acid are transfer, ribosomal & messenger

(3, 4).clue: Matt Damon plays a young lawyer in trouble in this "stormy" flick

(4, 4).clue: From 1952 to 2001 the Bill of Rights was on display in the Exhibition Hall of this building in Washington, D.C.

(5, 4).clue: This author's "An American Tragedy" was based on a real-life murder case

(6, 4).clue: It's the notch that fits on the bowstring in the non-business end of an arrow

(1, 5).clue: When a 1918 treaty was signed there, the name of this city in Belarus included Litovsk

(2, 5).clue: One of the 4 nitrogen-containing DNA bases abbreviated A, G, T & C

(3, 5).clue: Chris O'Donnell plays a lawyer whose granddad faces the ultimate trouble--execution--in this title place

(4, 5).clue: In essay No. 84 in this series of letters, Alexander Hamilton argued against a Bill of Rights

(5, 5).clue: The title of this 1962 Faulkner novel refers to 3 young men who steal a car & take it for a joy ride

(6, 5).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew finishes chalking up his pool cue.)  Keep track of this part of the table, where I'm suavely setting down my chalk

(0, 0).clue: This search engine was co-founded by Sergey Brin, a math major who chose the name to imply a vast reach
